content.description: Long "crack."  You can see the "Z" from the road and the climb goes up the "crack" at the bottom of the "Z."  Mostly not crack climbing, slabby, chossy, face climbing.  The crux is at the "Z" where there is a corner roof crack which is actually really cool.  Do yourself a favor and climb the crack than using the face holds.  TONS OF LOOSE ROCK.  BECAREFUL IN NOT KILLING YOUR BELAYER
content.protection: Nuts, cams.  nothing above a 3. or 4 to be safe.  Small stuff for anchor.  Gear anchor at top.  We walked off right.  Probably need a 70 just to make it up.  Gear is...okay.  Crux is well protected
content.location: Hike to mini pinnacle and your halfway there.  Hike up ridge and you'll see it.  Scope it from the road so you know where you are going.

content.description: Longest route on tower. Crux is towards the top.  The most solid/easily protected line on the tower.  NU says 5.5 so thats what I listed it as.  Felt as hard as some 5.7s in the canyon
content.protection: Not great placements.  Some good nuts.  There is an old piton you can clip 2/3 up on the arete.  Don't need much gear because its so short.  Small cams.  Wrap down from two biners in the slings wrapped around the block on top.  Bring webbing/slings if you don't trust the stuff up there (it looks like its been there a while but my partner and I rapped off it today)
content.location: north west face.  climb the face using the arete, watch for choss, my partner pulled a cantaloupe sized rock off.
